questions.text: Drug induced ILD is caused by all EXCEPT?

This patient came to you with symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection. Incidentally, on physical examination, you noticed this general examination finding. This patient is at increased risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Frank sign refers to the presence of a diagonal crease in the earlobe that runs backwards from the tragus at a 45 degree angle across the lobule to the rear edge of the auricle.

CLINICAL RELEVANCE- It may be a predictor of coronary artery disease and/or diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: DLCO is decreased in all the following except ?
questions.solution: Pulmonary hemorrhage is characterised by increased DLCO.

questions.text: A 29 year old woman was found to have a Hb of 7.8 gm/dL with reticulocyte count of 0.8%. PS showed microcytic hypochronic anemia. Hb A2 and Hb F levels were 2.4% and 1.3% respectively. Serum iron and TIBC were 15 mgm/dL and 420 mgm/dL respectively. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Such a high level of TIBC with microcytic hypochronic blood picture is very much suggestive of IDA. Anemia of chronic inflammation usually have normocytic normochromic Red cells. Serum Ferritin is very important in diagnosing IDA and is usually < 15 ng/mL. Differential diagnosis of microcytic hypochronic anemia are :

questions.text: A 66 year old lady presented with swelling and pain in the area of left heel after a 2 week course of an antibiotic therapy for upper respiratory infection. MRI of the ankle region is shown. What is the likely antibiotic ?
questions.solution:
MRI of the ankle (shown in image) shows a near full thickness rupture of the Achilles' tendon. Tendonitis and rarely tendon rupture has been mentioned as an adverse effect of fluoroquinolones. Risk factors for tendonitis in patients on fluoroquinolone include :

  • Advanced age
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Concurrent steroid use

questions.text: What is the likely nutrient deficiency in this patient presenting with skin discoloration ?
questions.solution: Dermatitis due to niacin deficiency (pellagra) is characterised by erythema resembling severe sunburn. In the figure,appreciate the classic "Casal's necklace" around the neck and upper chest-pointed by red arrow.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient is being treated in the medical ICU for pneumonia. Since the culture yielded MRSA sensitive to Vancomycin, was started on the drug. Soon after drug administration he developed flushing, tachycardia and hypotension. What is the likely phenomenon that has occurred?
questions.solution: Rapid intravenous infusion of vancomycin can cause erythematous and urticarial reactions, flushing, tachycardia and hypotension. The extreme flushing that can occur is called redman syndrome. This is not an allergic reaction, but a direct toxic effect of vancomycin on mast cells, causing them to release histamine. It can be prevented by prolonging the infusion period to 1-2 hours or pre-treatment with an antihistamine like diphenhydramine.

questions.text: A 74-year-old male has previously worked as a plumber and has been exposed to asbestos. He has no previous respiratory problems and now has a chest X-ray before an elective hip replacement. What is the finding ?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrates extensive pleural plaques. These are evident both above the hemi- diaphragms and also along the ribs throughout the thorax. This is a benign condition and rarely causes symptoms. The plaques occur after a latent period of approximately 20-40 years following asbestos exposure and almost exclusively involve the parietal pleura.

The X-ray appearance in extensive pleural plaques is also called Holly Leaf Sign.

questions.text: Inverted V sign is a radiological finding in ?
questions.solution: The inverted "V" sign, also known as the inverted rabbit ears sign, is a radiological sign described in subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. It refers to the appearance of the spinal cord on axial MRI slices

questions.text: A patient admitted in ICU following head injury has developed hyponatremia. The serum osmolality is 272 mosm/kg and Urine sodium is 45 meq/l. The urine output is normal and patient is clinically euvolemic. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Low serum osmolality and increased urine sodium in a clinically euvolemic patient with a background history of head trauma suggests a diagnosis of SIADH.

questions.text: What is the gauge of the cannula shown below ?
questions.solution: Green cannula is 18G

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in this 28 year old male who presented with progressive generalised dystonia of 1 year duration.
questions.solution: In this patient with an extrapyramidal syndrome, the MRI is showing the "Face of Giant Panda" sign. The face of the giant panda sign in neuroimaging refers to the appearance of the midbrain, when the red nucleus and substantia nigra are surrounded by high T2 signal in the tegmentum. This is suggestive of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A 25 year old female presented to the emergency department with acute onset chest tightness and palpitations. Portion of ECG strip is shown. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: The strip is showing a regular narrow complex tachycardia suggestive of Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT).

questions.text: The below is the diagrammatic representation of the breathing pattern of a patient admitted in the medicine ICU with an acute onset breathlessness following chest pain. What is the pattern of respiration here ?
questions.solution: This is the classical Cheyne Stokes respiration. Its also referred to as waxing and waning type of respiration. It is seen in acute LVF, raised ICT and Narcotic poisoning. The patient in question is probably having acute left ventricular failure following an acute coronary event.

questions.text: Speckled appearance of myocardium in Echo is a feature of ?
questions.solution: "Speckled appearance" of myocardium in ECHO is a feature of cardiac amyloidosis. This is due to amyloid accumulation in the cardiac tissue.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the neurology clinic due to a history of seizures. As an infant, he was noted to have infantile spasms, and more recently has developed complex partial seizures with staring, lip smacking, and automatisms. He has minimally delayed language. What is the most likely diagnosis based on history and examination?
questions.solution: The image is showing ash leaf macules and Shagreen patches. These general examination findings in a patient with epilepsy is suggestive of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following has level A recommendation for mechanical ventilation in ARDS patients ?

A 29 year old male athlete suddenly collapsed and died during a football game. At autopsy the following finding was seen on gross examination. He had a history of two similar deaths in the family previously. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
This is a classical scenario of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy where sudden death can occur in young, otherwise normal athlete/adult. Family history of similar deaths further vindicates the diagnosis.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

  • Autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in one of the several genes encoding sarcomeric proteins (beta-myosin heavy chain, troponin T, Myosin binding protein C)
  • Characteristic feature:
    • Dynamic LV outflow obstruction and impaired diastolic filling due to:
      • Myocardial hypertrophy without ventricular dilation
      • Assymetric septal hypertrophy
      • Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve
    • Systolic function preserved with normal Ejection fraction and cardiac output

choices.text: Sputum AFB and PCR for TB

questions.text: A 65 year old male presents with chronic sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcers, cavitatory lung nodules and renal failure. What will be the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
Clues for diagnosis of Vasculitic disorders

  • lderly patient, headache in temporal region, symmetrical pain and stiffness in shoulder/hip , with jaw claudication and blindness / diplopia
    • Giant cell arteritis / Temporal arteritis (Rx: Systemic corticosteroids)
  • Young female, ocular disturbances, arm claudication / Raynaud's phenomenon, weakened pulses of upper extremity
    • Takayasu arteritis
  • Renovascular hypertension, digital gangrene, mononeuritis multiplex, association with Hepatitis B / Hairy cell leukemia, absence of glomerulonephritis, sparing of pulmonary artery
    • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Allergic rhinitis, asthmatic attacks with infiltrates and eosinophilia, mononeuritis multiplex
    • Churg Strauss syndrome (Rx: Cyclophosphamide)
  • Chronic sinusitis, nasal septal perforation, nasopharyngeal ulceration, persistent pneumonitis with cavitation of lung, focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis
    • Wegener’s granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangitis)
  • Children < 5 years, desquamative rash, erythema of hands and feet with peeling, non purulent conjunctivitis, lymphadenopathy, coronary artery aneurysms
    • Kawasaki’s disease (Rx: IV immunoglobulin)
  • Palpable purpura, peripheral neuropathy, Arthalgia-myalgia, glomerulonephritis, association with Hepatitis C
    • Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
  • Children 4-8 years, palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthalgia, glomerulonephritis
    • Henoch Schonlein purpura
  • Recurrent oro-genital ulceration, recurrent hypopyon/iritis/posterior uveitis, positive pathergy test, HLA B51 association
    • Behcet's disease

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic male is referred for evaluation of chronic right ankle pain. There is a distant history of trauma and poorly controlled diabetes. He denies podagra, and serum uric acid is normal. On examination he has fair peripheral circulation, pes planus with mild ankle tenderness at the tibiotalar joint, and glove and stocking neuropathy is present. His radiograph shows diffuse demineralization and Lisfranc dislocation of the midtarsus. The joint is tapped and hemarthrosisis noted. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: This patient has a classic Charcot joint, which is characterized by damage secondary to loss of sensation that occurs due to the patient's underlying diabetes. The features of a Charcot joint include fragmentation of bone, progressive destruction, and disorganization. Although there are many causes, diabetic neuropathy is the commonest cause in the western world. Lisfranc dislocation implies disruption of the joint between the rigid midfoot and more supple weight-bearing forefoot. Arthrocentesis frequently yields a hemarthrosis

questions.text: In a patient with chronic meningitis, the presence of (1,3)-b-D-glucan in the CSF implies that the underlying infectious agent is which of the following?
questions.solution: (1,3)-β-D-glucan is a cell wall component of several fungal species, so its presence in the CSF is a useful adjunctive test in establishing that the agent responsible for chronic meningitis is a fungus, but a positive result does not permit identification of the particular fungal species.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with memory loss over the last several months. He notes antecedent arthralgia, low-grade fevers, skin hyperpigmentation, and frequent diarrhea. On examination he has mild rigidity in his upper extremities, and concurrent slow pendular movements of the eyes and contraction of the masseter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Whipple disease is caused by an infection with Tropheryma whippelii, leading to low-grade fevers, arthralgia, diarrhea, muscle wasting, and hyperpigmentation. Neurological symptoms include extrapyramidal symptoms, limitations of vertical gaze, and characteristic oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pendular oscillations of the eyes with rhythmic contractions of the masticatory muscles). Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder resulting in accumulation of copper resulting in liver disease, movement disorders, and dementia. Fever and oculomasticatory myorhythmia are not present in Wilson disease. Neurosyphilis causes psychosis, agitation, aggression, dementia, multiple cranial neuropathies, and multifocal vasculitic infarcts. Early-onset Alzheimer disease presents with dementia but without systemic symptoms or movement disorders.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with longstanding Sjogrens syndrome presents with new onset of lethargy, hypokalemia, and nephrocalcinosis. Her metabolic profile reveals an anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia, and alkaline urine. A skeletal survey reveals diffuse osteopenia. What is the likely complication that has occurred ?
questions.solution: Renal Tubular Acidosis is a rare but important complication of SS. Distal RTA occurs due to failure to acidify urine to a pH < 5.3. This results in anion gap acidosis, hypokalemia, nephrocalcinosis, and bone demineralization. The lymphocytes that invade the tubular epithelial cells are CD8-positive, i.e., cytotoxic T cells and similar to those found in the salivary glands of patients with Sjögren’s syndrome. The same immunological process is probably operative in the renal tubulointerstitial tissue as in the salivary glands to induce the characteristic tissue changes of Sjögren’s syndrome

questions.text: Duration of continuation phase for drug sensitive pulmonary tuberculosis ?
questions.solution: Intensive phase is for 2 months and continuation phase for 4 months.

questions.text: Most common cause of renal artery stenosis in young adults in western countries ?
questions.solution:
FIBROMUSCULAR DYSPLASIA

  • Most common cause of renal artery stenosis in young adults in Western countries.
  • More common in females. Female:Male prevalence is 8:1
  • Most common histological variant of Fibromuscular dysplasia is Medial fibroplasia
  • Lesions are frequently bilateral
  • In contrast to atherosclerotic renovascular disease (which affects origin of renal artery frequently), fibromuscular dysplasia tend to affect more distal portions of the renal artery.
  • The iliac arteries are the limb arteries most likely to be affected by fibromuscular dysplasia
  • It is identified angiographically by a "string of beads" appearance (shown in image) caused by thickened fibromuscular ridges contiguous with thin, less involved portions of the arterial wall

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of extramedullary tumor :
questions.solution: Dear students, go through this table showing the differences between and extramedullary and intramedullary lesions

questions.text: Facial angiofibromas and collagenomas are seen in :
questions.solution:
MEN 1

  • Wermer's syndrome. Menin gene chromosome 11q
  • Triad of PPP......Parathyroid, Pancreatic islets, ant Pituitary
  • Most common feature – Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Most common enteropancreatic tumor associated – Gastrinoma
  • Most common ant pituitary tumor associated - Prolactinoma
  • Other features
    • Adrenal cortical tumors
    • Carcinoid tumors
    • Facial angiofibromas
    • Collagenomas
    • Lipomas

questions.text: Stamping gait is seen in :

A 30 year old female who was diagnosed with SLE - Lupus nephritis 4 years back, but lost to follow up, now presented with acute onset breathlessness to the emergency department. On examination, she had a pulse rate of 128/min, irregular. Auscultation revealed mid-diastolic murmur at the apex. There were bilateral basal crackles on auscultation. Serum creatinine was 4mg/dl. ECG is shown below. What would be the oral anticoagulant of choice for her ?
questions.solution: The patient in question has presented with an acute pulmonary edema, probably as a result of decompensated Atrial Fibrillation. Presence of MDM also suggests there might be an underlying mitral stenosis. So, definitely the patient requires anticoagulation in addition to management of acute pulmonary edema. Since she is having an underlying Chronic Kidney Disease, choice of anticoagulation has to be prudent. Dabigatran, Rivaroxaban and apixaban has renal excretion and hence not preferred in severe renal insufficiency. So, warfarin is preferred as its route of excretion is via the liver.

questions.text: Identify the device used for Left atrial appendage closure in patients with atrial fibrillation and may be useful in patients with recurrent cardioembolic stroke, not responding to anticoagulants ?
questions.solution: Watchman device is a parachute shaped device used for Left Atrial Appendage Closure in Atrial Fibrillation.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient with history of Trauma to the chest, presented with Hypotension, muffled heart sounds and raised JVP. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in a quantity suf­ficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade.

The most common causes of tamponade are idiopathic pericarditis and pericarditis secondary to neoplastic disease, tuberculosis, or bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic dissection, cardiac operation, trauma, and treatment with anticoagulants.

The three principal features of tamponade (Beck’s triad) are hypoten­sion, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent.

questions.text: The ECG below is diagnostic of?
questions.solution: In Mobitz type 1 Heart block/Wenckebech Phenomena, Gradually progressive PR interval prolongation occurs before the blocked sinus impulse, with the greatest PR increment typically occurring between the first and second beats of a cycle, gradually decreasing in subsequent beats. Shortening of the PR interval occurs after the blocked sinus impulse, provided that the P wave is conducted to the ventricle.

choices.text: There is no change in the click with squatting or standing.
A passive leg raise makes the click-murmur occur earlier.
A squat maneuver makes the click-murmur occur later.
The mitral regurgitant murmur does not change with positional maneuvers.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to your office for evaluation. She appears healthy and is not limited by physical activity. She says that she has occasional chest pains that occur at rest, often with a change in position. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 76 beats per minute and regular. Auscultatory findings are a midsystolic click followed by a 2/6 apical systolic murmur that radiates to her axilla. Which of the following dynamic physical examination findings would confirm your suspicion of mitral valve prolapse?
questions.solution: This 30-year-old patient presents with atypical chest pain, which may be associated with mitral valve prolapse. Mitral valve prolapse is essentially a mismatch of the left ventricular cavity size and the mitral valve leaflets, which are redundant. The classic bedside maneuver is the squat-to-stand maneuver; however, any maneuver that increases the left ventricular cavity size will delay midsystolic clicks and the mitral regurgitant murmur (Figure 2.A8). The Valsalva maneuver decreases venous return, which would result in a smaller left ventricle and thus an earlier mitral valve pro-lapse. A post extrasystolic beat (due to the compensatory pause), the passive leg raise, and squat (all would improve left ventricular filling) should actually delay mid-systolic clicks and murmur.

questions.text: The pulse tracing shown below is most likely that of a patient with:
questions.solution: Pulsus alternans (alternation of one strong and one weak beat without a change in the cycle length) occurs most commonly in left ventricular failure.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is used in the treatment of refractory ITP?
questions.solution: Romiplostim is a thrompoetin receptor agonist indicated for treatment of chronic refractory ITP. It is administered subcutaneously. Another thrombopoetin agonist is eltrombopag and is administered orally.

questions.text: A 80 year old male patient presented with complaints of exertional dyspnoea, chest pain and syncope. On examination, pulse-86/min regular, BP 160/90mmhg, Mid-systolic murmur heard in right 2nd intercostals space. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Exertional dyspnea, angina pectoris, and syncope are the three cardinal symptoms of AS.

On Examination, The carotid arterial pulse rises slowly to a delayed peak (pulsus parvus et tardus). A thrill or anacrotic "shudder" may be palpable over the carotid arteries, more commonly the left.

The LV impulse is sometimes displaced laterally in the later stages of the disease.

The murmur of AS is characteristically an ejection (mid) systolic murmur that commences shortly after the S1, increases in intensity to reach a peak toward the middle of ejection, and ends just before aortic valve closure. It is characteristically low-pitched, rough and rasping in character, and loudest at the base of the heart, most commonly in the second right intercostal space.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis
Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is brought into OPD by his family who are concerned that he is more somnolent than normal. On further history, they report that he has been having problems with morning headaches and does not feel very refreshed when he wakes up. An arterial blood gas is performed and reveals: pH 7.3, PCO2 57, PO2 70, HCO3 32. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The patient in question has a low pH (acidemia). The PCO2 value is high (respiratory acidosis) and the bicarbonate is high (metabolic alkalosis). The low pH in combination with the high PCO2 tells us that the respiratory acidosis is the primary process. The metabolic alkalosis is the compensatory process. Summary: A chronic respiratory acidosis with a compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of pain and swelling of the right Achilles tendon and left ankle. He has a previous history of uveitis on 2 occasions. He describes stiffness in his lower back, which is worse in the morning. Which disease best accounts for his symptoms?
questions.solution: Achilles tendinitis (enthesopathy), low back pain with morning stiffness, and uveitis are characteristic of spondyloarthropathies, such as ankylosing spondylitis. The other diseases do not predispose characteristically to back pain, uveitis, or enthesopathy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old male was seen with a history of recurrent oral ulceration. He has no other symptoms. Past medical history includes posterior uveitis and aseptic meningitis. On examination he has painful eythematous lesions on the anterior shins. Lab evaluation reveals a mild normocytic anemia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: This is a case of Behcet's syndrome complicated by erythema nodosum. This is a condition more commonly seen in people who live on the Silk route from the Mediterranean basin to China. There is a strong association with HLA B51. The disease is characterized by thrombophlebitis, recurrent orogenital apthous ulceration, posterior uveitis, and meningoencephalitis. Cutaneous findings include a positive pathergy test, pseudofolliculitis, or erythema nodosum. Rarely pulmonary artery aneurysms can occur.

choices.text: Jugular venous distension with prominent x descent

questions.text: All of the following constitute Beck's triad except:
questions.solution:
Beck's triad is a feature of cardiac tamponade. Pericardial knock is not a component of the triad.

CARDIAC TAMPONADE

  • Results from fluid accumulation in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles.
  • Quantity of fluid necessary to produce cardiac tamponade may be as small as 200 ml when the fluid accumulates rapidly to as much as >2000 ml in slowly developing effusions when the pericardium has had the opportunity to stretch and adapt to an increasing volume.
  • Causes
    • Most common causes of are idiopathic pericarditis and pericarditis secondary to neoplastic disease.
    • May also result from bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic dissection, cardiac operations, trauma and treatment of patients with acute pericarditis with anticoagulants.
  • Three principal features seen in severe cardiac tamponade are together known as Beck's triad:
    • Hypotension.
    • Soft or absent heart sounds.
    • Jugular venous distension with a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.
  • ECG findings
    • Reduced voltage and electrical alternans.
    • Reduced voltage is non-specific and can be caused by a variety of other conditions (eg:emphysema, infiltrative myocardial disease, pneumothorax)
    • Electrical alternans means beat to beat variation in both the amplitude and axis of the QRS complex.
    • It occurs due to large amplitude rhythmic swinging of the heart within the pericardial sac, in presence of a large pericardial effusion.
    • A minimum of 200 ml of fluid is required for manifestation of electrical alternans.
    • Electrical alternans is specific and pathognomonic, but relatively insensitive.

questions.text: Which one of the following DPP4 inhibitor is excreted unchanged in faeces and does not require any dose modification in renal disease?
questions.solution: Linagliptin is a DPP4 inhibitor that is predominantly excreted unchanged in faeces with metabolism of the drug playing a minor role in overall pharmacokinetics. It is a weak inhibitor of cytochrome P450. There is no dose adjustment required for linagliptin in renal failure patients.

questions.text: Which class of medications is the best choice for initial therapy of hypertension in diabetics?
questions.solution: ACE inhibitors have been shown to provide renal protection in patients with diabetes (types 1 and 2). Patients with albuminuria and hypertension will certainly benefit from an ACE inhibitor. Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) are not indicated for the primary treatment of hypertension in diabetics (or, really, anyone else). Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are a reasonable alternative in the hypertensive patient with albuminuria if an ACE inhibitor is not tolerated. Vasodilators and calcium-channel blockers are not optimal choices in this patient although non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) are an option for renal protection in patients with worsening albuminuria especially in those who cannot tolerate an ACE inhibitor or ARB

questions.text: Most common hormone pattern in non-thyroidal illness?
questions.solution: The most common hormone pattern in sick euthyroid syndrome (SES), also called nonthyroidal illness (NTI), is a decrease in total and unbound T3 levels (low T3 syndrome) with normal levels of T4 and TSH. The magnitude of the fall in T3 correlates with the severity of the illness.

questions.text: The following murmur pattern is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Ejection systolic/Midsystolic murmur
  • Crescendo-decrescendo configuration
  • Begins after S1 and ends before S2
  • Seen in Aortic stenosis, Pulmonic stenosis, HOCM, flow murmurs

choices.text: Removal of clot from cerebral circulation
Removal of clot from coronary circulation

questions.text: The following device is used in?
questions.solution: The device shown is the Amplatzer septal occluder used in the closure of ASD

questions.text: The below Chest Xray is that of a 58 year old chronic alcoholic who is admitted in the medicine ICU as a case of pneumonia. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution: The X-ray shows the Bulging fissure sign. The bulging fissure sign refers to lobar consolidation where the affected portion of the lung is expanded causing displacement of the adjacent fissure. This is often associated with klebsiella pneumonia.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents with right-sided weakness. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of his computed tomography scan findings?
questions.solution: The basal ganglia is a common location for primary intracerebral hemorrhage related to hypertension, which accounts for up to 10% of all strokes. Other common sites of hemorrhage include the pons, thalamus, cerebellum, and the deep subcortical structures. Pathologically, hypertension-related primary intracranial hemorrhages occur because of lipohyalinosis of the deep perforating arteries, which makes these small vessels highly sensitive to sudden changes in blood pressure. Venous sinus thrombosis can certainly lead to hemorrhage, but typically occurs in the territory of a draining vein. Atrial fibrillation could lead to hemorrhage, but most often is a secondary phenomenon after ischemia occurs. Amyloid angiopathy leads to amyloid deposition and microhemorrhages usually in the cortical regions of the brain (rather than the subcortical as in this case)

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with recently treated acute myelogenous leukemia now in remission is admitted to the hospital with lethargy, fever, and tachycardia. Blood cultures grow Pseudomonas that is resistant to cefepime. She is started on IV gentamicin. Five days after starting gentamicin, her serum creatinine rises from her baseline of 1.0 mg/dL to 2.4 mg/dL. No red or white cell casts are seen on her urinalysis. Her magnesium level is decreased at 1.5 mg/dL. Renal ultrasound is unremarkable with no hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of her acute kidney injury?
questions.solution: Several antimicrobial agents are commonly associated with AKI. Aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) and amphotericin B both cause tubular necrosis. Nonoliguric AKI (i.e., with a urine volume >400 mL/day) accompanies 10-30% of courses of aminoglycoside antibiotics, even when plasma levels are in the therapeutic range. Aminoglycosides are freely filtered across the glomerulus and then accumulate within the renal cortex, where concentrations can greatly exceed those of the plasma. AKI typically manifests after 5-7 days of therapy and can present even after the drug has been discontinued. Hypomagnesemia is a common finding. AKI secondary to acute interstitial nephritis can occur as a consequence of exposure to many antibiotics, including penicillins, cephalosporins, quinolones, sulfonamides, and rifampin. There is no reason for ischemic injury by history. There are no red or white cell casts or anything in the history to suggest glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: An 85-year-old man presented with headache and left-sided weakness. NCCT of the head showed a right frontal lobar intracerebral hemorrhage; results from CT angiography of the brain were normal. The patient takes warfarin for atrial fibrillation, and his international normalized ratio at presentation was 1.4. His medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and he also has dementia. What is the most likely cause of the hemorrhage?
questions.solution: Lobar hemorrhages in elderly patients are often secondary to cerebral amyloid angiopathy. Hypertension is the main risk factor for all intracerebral hemorrhages, but it usually affects deep penetrating vessels and causes hemorrhages in the basal ganglia, thalamus, brainstem, or cerebellum. Anticoagulant medications, such as warfarin, increase the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage for patients with cerebral amyloid angiopathy but are not the primary cause. An arteriovenous malformation would be unlikely given the normal findings with CT angiography of the brain.

questions.text: In a COPD patient, FEV1 50-80% of predicted falls under what severity of airflow limitation?
